39398827.review:
An interesting puzzle game, but I think it had potential to be better.

The puzzles are generally well put, although I was expecting some mechanics involving the mixing of different colors, which I think would've been pretty cool. Each level adds its own little gimmick, which helps keep the puzzles fresh, although they still get a bit repetitive. There are some "platforming" sections which give the game a little action between the puzzles, but they're all very similar, you just have to keep changing colors to make your path. There are also long, empty sections between areas which are there solely for the purpose of listening to the narrator while traversing them. The first time they're fine, but if you're backtracking to get the collectibles they're just very boring.

And now, we get to that. The backtracking. I understand that getting the collectibles is completely optional, but if you put something optional in your game, you better make it worth it, right? I think the backtracking in this game is completely pointless. Most of the time, the collectibles are behind a wall with a color you don't yet have, so you have to go back after getting it, completing ALL the previous levels of that area. What's the fun part about repeating the same puzzles you've already solved, in the exact same way? Having new colors doesn't make you able to complete previous levels in different ways. That is how it should've been, if they wanted to put backtracking in. At least make the backtracking interesting, and not repeating the same puzzles and going through the same long, empty sections, with nobody narrating anything.
There are a handful of collectibles which are actually interesting to get, which don't involve backtracking, but figuring a way to get to a certain place, solving "a puzzle within the puzzle". I think it'd have been much more fun if all of them were like this.

Besides that, the game is alright. The story seems interesting at first, but then doesn't really get developed at all. The soundtrack is nice and chill, and gets more intense in certain sections, which is cool. The graphics are simplistic and pleasant.

Overall, I'd give it a 7.5/10, as a game.

As a product, I don't think it's worth the full price. I'd only recommend buying it when it's 75% off or more.

38923720.review:
Hue had so much potential to be a great game, but it feels like the developers couldn't decide whether they wanted a platformer or a puzzler. Instead of doing one genre well, they did both poorly.

The game features a lot of slow walking around, especially during story segments where you walk through a boring environment while the story is narrated to you. The story is fine, but having to walk through a long hallway to kill time is annoying.

The platforming segments are just frustrating - they present no challenge to either your brain or your reflexes, and instead feel like pointless filler. The same exact type of platforming section is repeated multiple times within the game, sometimes even back to back. It almost feels patronizing considering this is supposedly a puzzle game.

The puzzles are okay, most are of average quality and the difficulty curve is fine. They never get challenging though - right before you might ramp up the difficulty, a new color or game mechanic is introduced and the difficulty curve starts over. Instead of iterating designs with the elements they had, they just added more elements.

What really annoys me is the lack of a proper checkpoint or rewind system - if you make one mistake in a room and die, you have to start completely over from the beginning of the room. Many of the game mechanics are deadly, such as spikes, lasers, thwomps, bottomless pits, etc. and you will die a lot from simple mistakes. The worst part is that I frequently knew exactly what I needed to do, but a simple mistake in execution meant I had to die and start completely over from scratch. I feel like a different choice of game mechanics could have made for a much more fun experience with a lot less death and restarts. At the very least, being able to rewind a few seconds or create quicksaves would be a much appreciated band-aid. The game recommends a controller but I really don't see how that would help.

Another major annoyance is that when you are selecting a color, your character keeps moving in the same direction even if you let go of all movement keys. Time is slowed down but it's still very annoying that you have no control over your character while selecting a color - the slow motion is very useful in execution-based situations and is completely ruined by the lack of control. Many of my deaths are attributed to this, and the game requires this kind of quick maneuvering frequently.

There are collectibles in the game, but their placements intentionally hostile to the player. You will frequently see an obvious collectible in a level that you don't have the right color to access until later in the game, meaning you have to backtrack or replay levels to access it. This is beyond lazy - none of the collectibles require any challenge or puzzle to access, so requiring the player to replay levels to reach the spot once they have the right color is just insulting. The fast travel system in the game only lets you travel to the start of huge sections of the game, there is no way to travel to a specific level without replaying all of the levels before it.

The color palette seems to have too many similar colors. These are not your typical shades of colors as you would expect from opening up MS Paint or Photoshop, these are hand-tuned colors to fit the theme and art style of the game. While it does make the game consistently look pleasant, it also makes it really hard to discern colors. I am not colorblind, and I frequently had trouble telling apart yellow from orange, pink from purple, and yellow from yellow-lime green because they were so close in shade, especially when various elements tweak the shade slightly. This meant I frequently selected the wrong color, half the time resulting in death.

As for the story, it's okay. Just okay. It explores some interesting ideas but never follows through with them, instead stopping short to move on to a different topic.

On the bright side, the art design is beautiful, and I'm a big fan of it. The music is also pretty good.

Overall, I'd rate the game at 5/10, which is average and not a bad score, but I can't recommend it for the asking price. Get it when it's on sale for 50% off or more.

38646220.review:
I don't quite remember where this game came from, as I am a pretty avid subscriber to Humble Bundle. It probably came from one of those. That said, this review will short.

Hue is a game that explores the ability of incorporating colors into puzzles. Say you need to get through a blue wall. If you have the blue piece of the ring, you can get through it. This can apply to just about any object, making just about anything of color invisible. This gets more and more complex as you go, as there are lasers, balloons on crates, springs that change color when you step on them, even boulders of various colors rolling after you.

There were a few moments where I had to use the "Restart Level" button from the menu. This does detract from the experience, and it gave me this feeling that I had done something wrong, when I had merely been going through the process of trying to solve the puzzle. There aren't many levels that will do this to you, as I can only count about 2 or 3 that were particularly specific in how the game developer wanted it to be solved. Most times, you are never painted into a corner that says you can't undo what you've done. Because you are able to push and pull crates with the action button, it gives you a lot of forgiveness in pushing things too far to one side, or needing to drag a crate here or there.

The music is amazing. It seemed to capture those moments that were dangerous, without overplaying itself. It also blends well into the background, so that solving the puzzles doesn't become difficult with a distracting background music. The voice acting is also great. There is a feeling of real emotion in the words, and it helps to draw a connection to the characters, as well as give a new insight, through the writing, on how we perceive colors.

I won't give away too much more with this game. It didn't require me to go outside of the game to find solution for it. I recommend it to those that are keen on solving puzzles of a creative nature. Few puzzles deal with the idea of making an object passable, while not moving it in the slightest.

BRAVISSIMO! I had heard good things about Hue, but my GAWD, what a fantastic experience. This is indie game perfection. I cannot find one fault with it. I can name perfect games on one hand (Spelunky and…?), and this one grabs the title.  It is now right up there with The Swapper as one of my two most favourite platform puzzlers of all time. 

The balance between head scratchers and skill-based puzzling is just right. The pacing is perfect, titrating out new colours and new mechanics at just the right speed. The voice acting is superb, the music is melancholic and beautiful. The end-game puzzles certainly had me stumped for long minutes – just the right amount of difficulty.

My favourite aspect was the sheer joy of colour swapping. Putting the colour wheel on the right stick, adding a nice whooshing sound as you engage, sprinkling lovely musical chimes as you spin through the colours and slowing down time as you do it, made the mechanic just feel so good. There’s nothing else like it in any other game.  

I completed the game but did not go back for all of the collectibles. If I weren’t a father of two with a full-time job, I probably would…

If you like platform puzzlers in any way, make sure you don’t miss this. It’s probably the best one out there.

37988833.review:
Not an original concept, but executed with very beautiful design and music...Sadly, I am mainly not recommending this one, because I don't feel the price fits the value for the game.

It is a cute little puzzle platformer where you have to change the color of the background in order to either make parts of the environment visible or invisible.  This concept uses more colors than I think I have seen the mechanism implemented before.

The puzzle design is not bad, but can feel a little repetitive and tedious, rather than a feeling of true accomplishment.  I don't feel like I really have to think, rather I have to do way too many mundane movements of self and blocks to move such a short distances.  I would much rather have level design that makes me think about the task at hand, rather than knowing what I have to do and just taking forever to execute!

I have said this before about other puzzles games..When you introduce new mechanisms, simply show how they work and then give the player interesting ways to apply them.  In this case, the same puzzles only more color only gets more tedious, rather than more challenging.

Not a bad game, but I don't think I can suggest it for the price...It is obvious that it has had a good reception, but it feels more like a $5 puzzler, rather than $15 title.

Too often, developers will create long and drawn out puzzles and levels, thinging they are adding value.  Novel ideas and levels adds value, long simple puzzles add frustration and boredom. 37941706.review:
Le concept du jeu me paraissait innovant et original, c'est pourquoi je me suis laissé tenter. Ne m'attendant pas à grand chose, j'ai été très fortement et très agréablement surpris.

Le jeu constitue une succesion d'énigmes que l'on résout en changeant les couleurs du monde. La progression, bien que linéaire, n'est pas lassante puisque de nouvelles mécaniques viennent s'ajouter et se mêler pour agrémenter le gameplay de nouveautés au fur et à mesure que l'on avance dans le jeu. Plus on avance, plus on débloque de nouvelles couleurs à maîtriser et plus la difficulté s'accroît, sans jamais devenir frustrante ou rebutante. On prend même plaisir à maîtriser plusieurs couleurs à la suite dans un puzzle basé sur la réactivité par exemple.

De plus, la bande originale et les dialogues collent parfaitement à l'univers. On voyage dans ce monde, coloré à nos souhaits, pendant les quelques heures de durée de vie du jeu : ni trop court, ni trop long. Au final on n'a ni le temps de décrocher, ni le temps de se lasser.

Seul bémol je trouve : le fait de devoir refaire une bonne partie des puzzles pour obtenir des collectibles inaccesssible  avant. C'est le seul moment où l'on peut s'ennuyer sur Hue puisque l'on perd le plaisir de la découverte de ses nouvelles mécaniques de gameplay.

Pour conclure, Hue n'est peut-être pas un chef-d'œuvre mais c'est une petite pépite de puzzle game relaxant qui vaut la peine d'être jouée et appréciée. D'autant plus que le message que fait passer le jeu est intéressant.

Je recommande vivement !

36227129.review:
HUEgazo!!

Me acerqué con dudas a este juego de puzzle, sin tener claro si aguantaría a lo largo de las horas la sorpresa inicial
por las mecánicas y la estética tan únicas que tiene. Pero lo cierto es que se muestra sorprendente durante las 9 horas que me ha llevado resolver todos los puzzles principales. También hay como objetivo secundario encontrar 28 llaves ocultas por el escenario, algunas bastante complicadas. De este objetivo he conseguido un 20% aprox. Dejando ya claro que la longitud no es un problema, decir que se mezclan algunas zonas que requieren algo de habilidad con los puzzles netamente intelectuales, en que no hace falta ser demasiado hábil con el mando. 

Para quien no conozca la mecánica, decir que se trata de un plataformas de avance lateral en que el protagonista tiene el poder de alterar el color de fondo del escenario para conseguir que los objetos del mismo color se mimeticen con el fondo y dejen de ser visibles, y por tanto dejen de ser un obstáculo. Con esta premisa tan simple y un puñado de colores diferentes el desarrollador se saca de la manga unos puzzles bastante imaginativos, donde cada poco tiempo se ofrecen retos de dificultad creciente. 

A nivel gráfico es minimalista pero bien resuelto y muy resultón. La música es agradable y no se hace pesada, y los efectos de sonido no desentonan en esta especie de cuento mágico. Las historia es sencilla, y no resta ni suma al desarrollo del juego, sólo ofrece un contexto agradable y una finalidad para la búsqueda de Hue, el protagonista.

En definitiva, juego más que recomendable, todo un descubrimiento y una demostración de que aún con pocos medios pero con las ideas claras se pueden hacer grandes cosas.

Saludos!!

36203306.review:
Hue is a charming 2D puzzle-platformer themed, as the title suggests, around color. Specifically, your character, a boy oddly named Hue, has the ability to change the color of the background, which has the side effect of making any onscreen object that matches the background temporarily cease to exist; barriers disappear, deadly lasers vanish, and crates that were formerly being lifted up by colored balloons fall to the ground. You start out with only one color available to you, but as the game progresses, you’ll gain access to a full rainbow of eight.

This may not sound like wildly inventive territory for a puzzle-platformer, and to be honest, it’s not; while I’m not aware of another entry in the genre that uses this specific color-switching mechanic, much of what you do still boils down to pushing Block X onto Switch Y, or getting a key to unlock the exit to the room you’re in.

But while Hue doesn’t reinvent its genre, it does what it does with ample polish. The difficulty curve is wonderfully smooth, with new puzzle elements being gradually and carefully introduced to ease you in. Checkpoints are forgivingly spaced at the beginning of each puzzle, and time slows down while you switch colors, giving you plenty of time to avoid a laser or solidify a crucial platform in mid-air. And while the story is simple - Hue embarks on a quest to rescue his disappeared inventor mother - it’s well told, through excellent voice-over narration. My only real complaint is that two pairs of colors (pink/fuschia and orange/yellow) are a tad too similar to consistently tell apart in the midst of gameplay, resulting in a few unnecessary deaths.

For any fan of puzzle-platformers, Hue comes highly recommended.

34899190.review:
I enjoyed this game because of its main mechanic, the color wheel. Basically you can change the color of the background to make objects of that same color blend into the background, which makes them temporarily disappear. The developer did a great job of filling the world with fun puzzles in a vivid world.

My only complaint really is that the structure ends up being very repetitive. There are eight colors, and each color's gauntlet is essentially structured the same. First you are forced to walk through a maze while a voice-over reads the story, but there's no way to skip this or reach the end of the maze before the voice finishes. Then you solve the puzzles, which can sometimes be a bit too easy and repetitive as well. And then you obtain the next color for the next area. I suppose it's simple and it works, but they could have probably done something slightly less predictable.

Overall it was a fun experience, with definitely a lot of effort put into it.

33734423.review:
A dull, shallow game about changing colors and moving boxes. And moving boxes. And moving even more boxes.

Normally, I don't write reviews for games I don't especially like since they aren't worth the time to dole out a simple 6 or 7 and be done with it. They're mediocre, but never offensively bad. Hue is the straw that breaks the camel's back and is everything wrong with indie platformers in this day and age. It's all frills and dressing, but no substance. It's all about flash and pomp, but as shallow as a puddle when it comes to gameplay.

You play as the eponymous Hue, a kid who's looking for their missing mother and along the way, discovers the power to render the world in specific colors to get by obstacles and clear rooms. On paper, it sounds like nothing special but with a lot of room for potential. However, I don't think I've ever played a game that so undermined its own concept to the point where the puzzles are both tedious and mind numbingly easy. Boiled down, puzzles are based around the concept of making certain props vanish or appear based on the color you select. Instead of having creative enemies, platforming, color combinations, or anything remotely in-depth that would require strategy, the developers present the player with two types of puzzles. Reflex puzzles, which can be fun but are still relatively easy, where you switch colors to avoid obstacles and jump from platform to platform. These are okay.

Box puzzles, which make up the vast majority of puzzles in this game, are not okay. These puzzles require you to push or move boxes in specific colors or ways, sometimes swapping the colors four to five times just to reach one end of a platform to another to block a specific laser from zapping you, in order to reach a key, and then repeat that in reverse order, spending a good minute or two getting through it while thinking over the puzzle takes no more than 10 seconds to figure out. I don't understand why the developers would limit themselves to puzzles that remain the worst aspect of other puzzle games such as Professor Layton, but without any ounce of charm, endearment, be it through visuals or music.

From a graphical standpoint, the game relies too much on minimalism to hide the lack of thought and effort that went into the game. Details are limited to prefabricated tiles, backgrounds, and occasionally items in the world, and partway through, I found myself somehow wanting to play Fez instead. Fez, for all its faults, had gorgeous artwork and environments that still hold up today. Hue, on the other hand, is like looking at a sheet of charcoal with bright primary and secondary colors interspersed through outlines and empty space. Normally, I'm not too hard on artstyle choice or graphics, but when the gameplay is irritating and dull, it makes me wish I was playing a Professor Layton game instead. At least those games had a wonderful variety of puzzles, charming characters, and a cozy aesthetic with wonderful soundtracks.

In other words, if you like games that try to dress themselves up as being particularly deep or introspective without having an ounce of anything fruitfal, or if you have a particular fondness for puzzle games that are more like chores than actual puzzles,  then maybe this is the game for you. Otherwise, I cannot recommend Hue to anybody in particular. It does too little of anything to leave an impression and too much tedium to make it worth revisiting. Avoid it and save your money.

3/10.

33578879.review:
Hue is a puzzle platformer that makes you think about the world in a different way in the form of colors. It has a pretty basic story with Hue's Mother working on some sort of device with another professor and his mother gets stuck in another spectrum. It's up to Hue to use the powers of color , solve puzzles , and find your mother. All while unraveling the story as it goes on.

Pros:
-Game has a great simplistic art style that makes the colors pop.
-Gameplay feels damn good, tight controls , the color wheel feels fantastic esp with a controller.
-Game is a good 5-10 hours , unless you're some sort of wizard. I have seen some 3-4 hr runs listed via reviews.
-Puzzles range from super easy to absolute pain in the a**. Esp by the end of the game ,  some of those last few puzzles will make you rage.

Mixed:
-The music is fantastic but there's too much of the same song looped over and over. I get there's supposed to be some tone set with this , but do I really need to solve challenging puzzles to somber piano music or just small drum beats?

Cons:
-Map feature is garbage. You have to pause the game to go into the map and it's just icons with numbers representing how many secret beakers you found , should be somewhat more in depth. I kinda wish they'd consider changing it. This would also help a lot with people who want to collect all the beakers. And in general just help with the flow of the game. I actually screwed up and went a different route and had to redo a series of puzzles to get back to the lighthouse area.
[spoiler]-There's a puzzle near the end of the game where there's a purple and a aqua spout that move back and forth , and theres a lever and a switch. The team actually changed where the switch was initially and made this puzzle really f'ing annoying to solve. Watch a lets play and you'll see what I mean.[/spoiler]

Hope that helps. Definitely check it out if you're jonesing for a good Puzzle game and support stuff like this. I wonder if they would make another one.

33064187.review:
Hue makes me tickled pink, but that might be because I'm looking at it through rose-colored glasses. Other game developers must be green with envy because of what Fiddlesticks Games have accomplished. If you haven't guessed by now, Hue is a game about puns. No wait, that's not right. Hue is a 2D puzzle-platformer that involves the region of the electromagnetic spectrum between the wavelengths of 400 and 700 nanometers. It's a game about color, and it is excellent.

In Hue, you play as Hue, and change the hue. What a delightfully simple concept. Charmingly voiced by Anna Acton, who gingerly guides the player with some conveniently-placed letters, you will be treated to a loosely-defined story about love and perspective. You must find the author of these letters who has found themselves trapped outside the monochrome world. The young boy, Hue, must find eight colors: red, orange, yellow, lime, aqua, blue, purple, and pink. As Hue stumbles upon each, he gains the ability to change the background to that pigment at the press of a button. Changing the color of the background is surely a novelty. You can't make a platformer based on that alone, can you? Well, color me impressed, you can.

Whenever the background changes, all items in the world matching that color will effectively cease to exist. Boxes, ledges, balloons, lasers, and deadly boulders disappear from the world until the background is switched again. To get through a red wall, Hue can switch to red and now there is no wall. So, basically, Hue can give himself the red carpet treatment at any time. This color swapping is used well for both puzzles and platforming.

On the puzzle side, you might have to place an orange box behind a yellow one by making one invisible and dragging the other through it. You can use these boxes to trigger pressure switches that open doors by cycling through the palette. Later, Hue will need to deal with lasers that instantly kill and nozzles that spray paint to change the color of objects. There are even platforms that will cycle through to the next color each time Hue jumps on them. In all these cases Hue will need to consider his surrounds and swap to the correct color(s) to complete the puzzle.

While the puzzle side of things sounds basic, the implementation is nearly perfect. If it weren't for a few boxes getting caught on flat surfaces and dodgy ladders, there wouldn't be any issues with the mechanics. The gradual introduction of new devices matches the need to think in multiple colorized dimensions. Most of the puzzles take place in fairly small rooms, often with a key that needs to be acquired to open the exit. These contained areas ensure the puzzles are fairly manageable despite their purplexity. Most puzzles cannot be broken, so the game allows players to try bad solutions, before moving onto greener pastures.  While the game world is not strictly linear, the acquisition of colors and their corresponding areas tends to follow a direct route for a smoother experience.

The hectic platforming sequences are interspersed between these chains of puzzle rooms. Platforming challenges require much faster switching between colors, as you avoid deadly obstacles. Fortunately the swapping of colors slows time, providing a fraction more tolerance to make the required jumps. Nevertheless, some of these sections are tricky. Ledges will crumble and boulders will tumble. You need to quickly determine whether you want a specific color enabled or disabled. Pick the wrong color and you'll be black and blue all over. 

These faster platforming sections can take a minute or two to complete and have a small margin for error. The tolerance for making some vertical jumps is fairly low; Hue might need to quickly swap colors after jumping up through an invisible platform. Horizontal jumps are sometimes made in advance of seeing what color needs to be disabled or enabled. In both cases, the main caveat is that the background cannot be changed when Hue is inside an object, so there is a little bit of dexterity involved. Platforming is also made a little harder because the swapping color wheel can obscure nearby ledges. While there will be a few deaths during platforming, the difficulty is quite fair when contrasted with the slower puzzle challenges.

These two main parts of the game provide a good balanced mix. None of the puzzle mechanics are overused, and the same is true with the slightly different faster challenges. Both elements get slightly trickier as the game progresses, following the general blueprint set by similar platformers. The game will take around four hours to complete, with more time needed to backtrack and collect some achievement-related objects. It’s a good length and there is plenty of variety. 

Fiddlesticks Games have done the impossible—they've hit a purple patch after creating only one game. Hue is a 2D platformer that cleverly integrates the switching of background colors. Switching between each pigment will make objects invisible or visible, necessary to complete the good-sized puzzle rooms and leap onto ledges in the frenzied platforming sequences. Mechanically it is quite sound, with only a few red flags linked to boxes and ladders. After finishing Hue, there will be no grey area—this is a blue ribbon experience worth every cent of your greenback-equivalent.

It is hard not to recommend Hue. It is a charming, inventive little puzzle platformer and you surely have not played anything like this before. However, don't go in expecting the best puzzle game experience you have ever gotten - the game has its down moments.

Hue revolves around a clever color changing mechanic where you can control the background color of the stage. However, in my opnion the game falls short on discovering this mechanic to its fullest potential. The game tries to add more complexity by adding more colors to your wheel but ends up using only about 5 of the colors in the later levels. When most of the wheel colors have been opened, I had to turn on the colorblind mode to make things clearer.

Most of the game is moderately easy - you can proceed with flying colors. During the last hour of the game the difficulty ramps up. Some of the puzzles near the end are great, some just make you frustrated for other reasons than not figuring out the solution. 

All in all, the game sort of fails to surprise player with its puzzle design. Nothing that Hue 2 cannot fix. Still a unique experience that is worth having.

32400262.review:
I got this off a humble bundle.

As a puzzle platformer, this does a lot of things well. It's a challenging, charming game at times and the initial hook is pretty decent. It's also for the most part fun. There's a story there but it's paper thin and the music is basic but nice enough. It's a good game for a quiet change of pace.

However, once the story is over, it's not worth playing again. The collect-em-all side quest which can't be completed until you finish the story really is a showcase for the games flaws. You repeat the same puzzles over again, areas where the collectables are do not offer any new challenge and are usually hidden in inaccessable holes in already completed puzzles. Without the story, the bits which had the exposition are now shown to be long featureless, puzzleless corridors, something you don't notice on the initial playthrough, but are very apparent and shows a bit of disappointing programming and you eventually realise how repetitive this game can be at times. 

That's not to say it's not fun. It really is. But only once, because of this and the length of time to complete the game I would recommend not getting it at full price, wait for a bundle or a sale, but I would say £6/£7 is about the most you should pay.

tl;dr Fun puzzle game with flaws that are hardly noticible the first time you run-through, very much so when going for 100%. Too expensive though, buy on sale.

32227352.review:
Hue is a 2D puzzle platformer where you can manipulate the world by altering the background color of the levels. You play as the small boy Hue looking for his lost mother.

[h1]Visuals[/h1]
The art in Hue is rather stylistic and vibrant. Some graphical elements are little amateurish, but overall the game looks quite beautiful and unique.

[h1]Audio[/h1]
The sound effects and voice acting are decent enough. Music is quite nice too, even if slightly repetitive.

[h1]Gameplay[/h1]
Pretty much all the puzzles and action sequences in Hue are built around the color switching mechanic. Any map elements that match the current color of the background simply disappear temporarily and you can freely pass through them.

This mechanic is then used in various puzzles and more action-oriented platforming sequences. While the color switching itself is quite an clever idea and the game keeps adding more potential colors to the mix, the actual puzzles remain fairly simple. I would have liked to see bit more depth and complexity with the puzzle design myself.

One minor annoyance is also the lack of checkpoints during the levels. Some of the larger levels take a while to go through and the game has quite a few hazards that can kill you.

[h1]Difficulty[/h1]
Hue is a rather easy game, only the last few puzzles are slightly more complicated.

[h1]Controls[/h1]
Controls are somewhat floaty and not terribly precise on a gamepad. At least the game doesn't really require precision jumping.

[h1]Story and Writing[/h1]
The writing is solid enough and the story is fairly interesting, if rather short.

[h1]Bugs and Glitches[/h1]
Boxes can sometimes get stuck on other objects when you push them around.

[h1]Final Verdict[/h1]
Hue is a pretty decent puzzle platformer with an interesting color manipulation mechanic and decent visuals. I wasn't a massive fan of many of the actual puzzles, however. I would still recommend the game, especially to the fans of the genre.

It took me around 3.5 hours to finish the game.

31641147.review:
[h1]Hue——一部关于颜色，创意十足的小品级解密游戏[/h1]
花了大概三小时通关了Hue的主线，还剩几个奖励关卡没通，深深感受到了作者的脑洞和创意。
玩家需要通过改变主题色使墙壁，箱子，陷阱等显示或消失，同色消失，异色显现，再来考虑如何移动箱子，填补陷阱来到达每关的终点。
刚开始玩家只有一个颜色，随着关卡的进行，玩家可改变的颜色越来越多，谜题也就随之越来越难，最终玩家一共可改变的颜色有八种，当八种颜色的箱子，墙壁，陷阱等堆在一个关卡里，如何巧妙改变颜色使物品显示或消失并且移动，是这个游戏的内核机制。
作为一个横版解密游戏，做到有趣和烧脑是一件很困难的事情，Hue在整个难度节奏的把控做得相当到位，既不会因为太难而劝退一部分玩家，也不会因为过于简单而显得无聊。整个风格，包括画风和解密，还是偏休闲的，不用担心卡关。
当然，这个游戏的难度对我来说，还是相对简单了一点，也许是流程太短，玩完还意犹未尽。到了游戏后期，解密难度降低，而对操作要求变得高了起来，这样的设计好不好，见仁见智。
总体来说，Hue整体质量上乘，但是作为一个主线仅有3小时的游戏来说，卖48显得性价比并不是很高，游戏有收集要素的存在，但我不认为会有很多人为了全收集而重玩这个游戏。
7.5/10

31593547.review:
[b]HUE is a puzzle-platformer where you change the background color to solve the puzzles. This concept is way more interesting than it might sound, I suggest to watch a video to fully understand it. The gameplay is fun, the controls are very good even with k+m (although the devs recommend a controller). The difficulty and variety of the puzzles rise with time perfectly. The lenght of the game is perfect for such a game in my opinion. It took me ~5 hours to beat it. The visuals are minimalistic yet charming but some people might not like it. The music and dubbing are pleasant.[/b]

[b]STORY[/b]
The story is okay. It is linear and quite simple as you'd expect from a puzzle game. You are looking for your lost mother. The story reveals mainly through monologues of the main character's mother. You can interact with most of the characters in the game if you want to know more about the Hue's world or just to hear a funny joke. It has no impact on the story though.

[b]GAMEPLAY[/b]
It is the most enjoyable part of the game. The devs recommend a controller to play the game but I have played with keyboard and mouse. Still, it was a lot of fun. I had to get used to controlling the character with WSAD but it wasn't much problem. Have in mind though that you will probably have to control the character with left hand too because you will need the mouse to change the colors of the background. I haven't checked if the keys are rebindable. The lenght of the game was perfect for me personally (~5 hours) but some people might be disappointed it is too short. The puzzles' difficulty was rising with time perfectly but generally it isn't a hard game. New features appear systematically so you won't get bored with the same kind of puzzle over and over again. The puzzles require a bit of thinking and a bit of reflex.

[b]VISUALS[/b]
Personally I liked the artstyle of the game but it is a matter of one's taste. For me it fitted the concept of the game (changing the background colors) perfectly. If you are a demanding gamer in terms of graphics just check the screenshots to see if it is something you will like. The variety of levels' design was okay.

[b]SOUND[/b]
The music is minimalistic but charming and pleasant. The only dubbing you will hear is mother's voice reading the letters to her son. The rest of the characters are quiet but you can interact with them.

[i]Don't mind my recommendation because it is only my subjective opinion which shows if I've enjoyed the game or not. If you are considering buying this game, read the review and decide yourself.[/i]

Hue ha sido para mi una grata sorpresa en el mundo de las plataformas con puzzles por su interesante mecánica de juego su apartado gráfico bien cuidado y una banda sonora que te acompaña durante toda la aventura.

No es un juego muy difícil y las nuevas mecánicas se van aprendiendo según avancemos en la historia, por lo que en algunas partes puedes quedarte algo encallado si se te escapa algún detalle, y a pesar de ello da la sensación de que es incluso corto.

[list]

    [*]Banda sonora
    [*]Controles (muy recomendado el uso de mando)
[/list]

CONTRAS:
[list]
    [*]Duración (puede parecer corto)
[/list]

Si te gustan los juegos de puzzles y las plataformas te recomiendo este título ya que es una agradable experiencia de juego. Una joyita a tener en cuenta.

색깔을 잃어버린 나라에서 색깔을 알아낸 어머니를 찾는 한 소년의 모험.


어느 날 일어나보니 어머니가 사라져버린 휴는 어머니를 찾기 위해 어머니가 남겨놓은 단서인 편지를 읽으면서 어머니의 발자취를 추적해나간다. 그리고 색이 없는 나라에서 휴는 색을 하나하나 찾아낸다.

게임 스토리 자체는 무난무난하다. 그냥 게임 컨셉이랑 어느 정도 잘 어울리는 느낌. 다만 문제는 게임자체가 너무 쉽다는 것. 물론 후반부 퍼즐은 좀 어려운데 어려운 퍼즐은 뒤에 10개도 안 되는 게 문제이다. 또 색깔을 바꾸면서 퍼즐을 푼다는 개념은 처음에는 약간 신선하기는 했으나 시간이 갈수록 색깔이 늘어나는 게 무슨 의미가 있는지 알기 어려웠다. 사실상 색깔 3~4개로만 퍼즐을 만들어도 동일한 퍼즐이 나오는 경우가 너무 많았다.


이런 류의 게임을 너무 많이 하다보니 딱 10분만 해도 견적이 나오는데 처음 10분해보고 게임의 한계를 느꼈고 그건 게임 끝날 떄까지 변하지 않았다. 차라리 비슷한 스토리의 테슬라그라드 혹은 베슬같은 게임 하는 걸 추천한다.


평점 : 6/10

30965358.review:
Hue is a 2D platform puzzle game that I just stumpled upon and let me tell you, I did not know what to expect from it. You control a little guy named Hue that is running around, collecting colours and on his way he finds out about his mother's research about colours. The world they live in is black and white and his mother "discovered" colours.

The concept is so nice, I have never seen another game like this. There probably is, but I may not know of it. Do not expect a fully blown story about whatever thing, it is short, but really nice to listen to and it sometimes rises some questions inside your head. I never expected that this game would blow my mind with just simple statements or questions.

The soundtrack is amazing and really calming, the colours are really nice to look at and, overall, the art style is stunning. Simple, but stunning. All the little details are really cute and immersive. For example, when you hit something that is hanging from the ceiling, it will move and make a specific noise. The attention to detail is amazing.

As a puzzle game, I, personally, found it easy, I did not struggle to find out the solution, but as you progress, they do get from hilariously easy to challenging ones, that make you think even a little bit.

Something I did not like about it was the fact that it was so short. I did not try to get through fast, not at all. I would have liked it to be a little bit longer.

I want to thank the developers for bringing us such a nice little game and so many interesting concepts that I, for once, never thought about. Thank you.

30947705.review:
Really nice game. Clever level design, a nice diversity of puzzles. Even has a bit of a story to tie the levels together. Take a look at the screenshots to see if you like the art style (I did).

Pretty easy to 100%, though I don't mean to imply it's an easy game. A few of the puzzles took some real work! Also, I needed a guide to find a few of the collectibles (beakers) I'd missed.

One thing to note is that while most of game relies on solving puzzles, there are sections that require some quick reflexes, timed jumps, etc. So if you want "pure" puzzling, you might be turned off by that.

30938403.review:
Hue me ha vendido el bundle "mensual" de G2 A, no sé si eso es suficiente recomendación. Pero vamos, que he conseguido este juego con otros 4 por menos de 4 euros.

Al principio no me había llamado demasiado la atención, hasta ver en Game Maker's Toolkit un vídeo hablando de sus mecánicas. A priori me recordó mucho a Nihilumbra que me había gustado, pero le faltaba algo.

Lo compré, lo empecé a jugar y me enganchó. Aparte de un problema con el fondo negro del juego "sucio" que no sé si es algo del mismo juego para darle algo de textura o un problema de mi pantalla, en general no he encontrado nada malo en el juego, lo que por desgracia a estas alturas (y pendiente de reseñar Reigns, Dusty Revenge y Valiant Hearts) es algo a agradecer.

Me gusta que no tiene complejas instrucciones ni tutoriales largos, el juego te va enseñando lo que necesitas y vas mejorando y consiguiendo nuevos colores y se van usando de formas diferentes según avanzas. Para el que no lo haya visto la mecánica es sencilla, puedes cambiar el color del fondo para ocultar objetos de ese color y mostrar otros de otro color. Sin más es el típico plataformas de puzzles, que es un género que me encanta.

Yo he encontrado algunas dificultades extra, pero me temo que era más por mi torpeza o por mi mando, en las zonas en las que hay que cambiar rápido de color, pero con repetirlas suficientes veces se superan.

Los coleccionables (las pociones) no siempre son fáciles y obvias de encontrar y yo opté por mirar en una guía en que puzzles aparecían para no perder más tiempo aún registrando cada pared. Luego descubrí que en el mapa puedes volver a zonas anteriores sin tener que caminar hasta ellas (el único problema de no tener instrucciones o tutorial).

La historia no es nada novedosa para alguien de mi generación que se ha pasado gran parte de la infancia siguiendo a Marco en su búsqueda de su mamá. Pero yo agradecí mucho que una vez que acabas y puedes seguir jugando cambie el aspecto de la ciudad y los diálogos de los PNJs.

Me han sorprendido mucho los diálogos de los PNJs, que tengan tres interacciones diferentes y que te den algo de información y te cuenten algo gracioso le da un plus al juego.

Tengo que reconocer que he tenido que buscar ahora en youtube porque no recordaba la música del juego. No molesta y es relajante, invita a concentrarte tanto que ni te acuerdas de ella.

Me fastidia sobre manera que he perdido mucho tiempo en la última pantalla por intentar resolverla de una forma mucho más difícil de lo que era, y en algunos puzzles me ha pasado que me costaba ver la solución mientras otros me parecían muy obvios pero no era capaz de hacerlo por falta de habilidad.

Para a alguien que le guste el género de puzzles creo que es un "must have" y seguramente se juega mejor en episodios y no todo a la vez como hice yo, que acabé bastante quemado, pero muy satisfecho al conseguir acabarlo todo de una sentada por lo mucho que me engancharon sus mecánicas y su atmósfera.

Hue was introduced to me on Twitter when the developpers followed everybody who had an interest in gaming, and each of their profile transpired seriousness, commitment, passion and pride that Hue demonstrate.


From the screenshots, it was visually appealing, the gameplay description seemed original and fun, so I was really determined to buy this game 1 year since now.

I bought it 3 days ago and I don't regret it. The trailers and comments did not lie on the quality of the gameplay, and the story is quite interesting and cute.


It is entertaining as a little puzzle game weither you are a casual of 8yo, or when you're a professional of 50yo.

So, yes, the puzzles and gameplay are simple, and not deeply challenging on your reflexes, but Hue is far from being mind-numbing and still fun for a chill time .

A wide world where the story was written in depth considering the shortness and simplicity of the game, even though the environment doesn't really makes sense with the story. 
But why put limits for the sake of logics? =P

The design side managed colours very well. 
The fact that it is a colour-based game can seem daunting because you could expect it to become psychedelic or busy,  but on the contrary, it is harmonious without overpowering your screen with screaming colours.
I like how you can change the colour at will therefore, not binding the colours solely to resolve puzzles.

The music is very good and puts you in the ambiance without overpowering the environment.
The voicing of the mother is very soothing and well placed in the game: you're not busy during puzzles, nor motionless waiting for the storyline to move on.

I don't want to say that it is greatly original, because there are a lot of patterns that have been done before, but of course, there are executions that make Hue stand out from the pack when you get to play it, especially at first glance with its children-book aesthetic but gloomy feel.


I do regret that it is so short, but that is just a personnal opinion.

30379583.review:
You control a little guy wearing a tie, similar to the main character "Tim" in the award-winning indie game, Braid.
The gameplay may, at first, seem to be a simple platformer, but do not be fooled.  It is a deep exploration of a single creative mechanic; use lateral thinking and your "magic verb" to get past an array of mental challenges.  The easiest comparison I can make is to Jonathan Blow's famous first project, Braid.
The game is divided into different zones that present different twists on the main gameplay idea.  I believe the first game to use this structure is the well-known time-reversing platformer game, Braid.
The story is told in vagueries, mixing simple emotional hooks with philosophical discussion.  Themes include the subjectiveness of human experience, the sacrifices one makes to quest for knowledge, and the melancholy of remembering better times.  You may notice that these are quite similar themes to a certain other game.
There are optional hidden items to collect across the game world.  I did not, personally, find every one of them, but I wouldn't be surprised if doing so caused the ending of the game to change significantly, since that is one of the most talked-about features of what I believe to be the primary inspiration for this game (Braid, Number None Inc., 2008).

Final Score: 2.71828 Braids out of 5

Hue is a game simplistic in style and deep in gameplay. One of the most difficult puzzle-platformers I've ever played. Difficult, but not punishing, the game never throws crazy surprises just to screw with the player, but simply has a steep learning curve. 

That was good. The story behind Hue is threadbare, but sufficient. You (the titular Hue) are trying to find your missing mother. 29829181.review:
Hue is a delightful puzzle-platformer with a interesting machanic that makes for a charming, unique puzzle game that I would recomend to anyone interested.
The machanic pretty simple. You have a color wheel, and you can use it to change the color of the background. Any objects in the foreground that match the color of the background will dissapear. Not just invisible, but completly cease to exist (if you've ever played Runbow, this probably sounds familiar). They can easliy be brought back into existence by changing the background color again. You'll have to use this to solve your way through lots of tricky scenarios and avoid deadly traps. The game gets more advanced by adding not only more items to interact with, but more colors to use on your color wheel.
This game looks fantastic, and since the game is based on colors - and therefore visuals - it's really important that it does! The art style is great, most of it being silhouttes (they can't exactly use colors, after all).
This game's pacing is incredibly good for a puzzle game. The game can kind of be divided into three different kinds of levels:
Mostly, there a puzzle rooms. These are rooms that present you with a challenge to solve at your own pace, using the tools you have.
Often, you'll get a break from puzzles and have to get through what I call an action room. These rooms don't require solving - instead, you'll need to use your color wheel to dodge obstactles and navigate platforms (think of Runbow, except you control the color of the background). There are a lot more puzzle rooms than action rooms, but the bursts of energy sprinkled about the game can help give you brain a break without losing your engadgement completely.
Lastly, there are narrative rooms. This game does have a story, and it tells that story by having you walk down an effortless hallway while narration happens. Not the most interesting way to tell a story, but the story is pretty simple, and actually pretty touching at times. A majority of the narration is letters that you're "reading" (listening to), so it feels a lot like flipping through diary pages more than a heavy plot. A lot of the entries explain backstory, but some of them are just sweet, and a surprising amount of them are pretty deep. Nothing that will radically change your life, but interesting food for thought nonetheless.
Overall, this game has a fun new puzzle machanic, gorgeous visuals, great sense of pacing and a story that is enjoyable enough that it doesn't feel like it gets in the way. Easily one of my favorite puzzle-platformers of all time, and I highly recomend you gvie it a try if it strikes you as something you'd like!

29477127.review:
[h1] In Hue, you play as the titular young man and go on a platforming, puzzle-solving, colour-swapping adventure to find your mother. [/h1]

Your mother is missing. She is a brilliant inventor—perhaps [i]too[/i] brilliant because as a result of her tinkering, she now resides past the visible colour spectrum in what is known as impossible colours. You must use the Amular Spectrum—a device your mother created that can shift the very colour of the world around you—your problem solving hat, and your lightning quick reflexes in order to gather up all the colours, find your mother, and live happily ever after.

Gameplay consists of a series of areas in which you need to solve a puzzle in order to continue to the next area. Progression is blocked off by obstacles that are a colour (or two) not yet found on your Spectrum and so you’ll need to find the appropriate colour before you can proceed. This forces you to approach the game in a linear fashion, which makes sense because Hue is heavily story-driven. More on that in a moment. 

Puzzles are intuitive and, more importantly, satisfying to solve. They are challenging, but not impossible after some careful examination and reevaluation of your approach. They come in a few flavours:

[list][*]The standard move from point A to B. Whether that means moving boxes to maneuver your way up, activating a series of switches, or working your way through a labyrinth of colours, these are the most common types of puzzle.
[*]Mad dashes, during which you’ll avoid obstacles from above and below. The ability to change colours on the go, which subsequently slows time a smidge, allows Hue to employ some very intuitive puzzles. Revealing and jumping to the next platform while the one you were just standing on disappears and making falling objects disappear harmlessly into their corresponding colour has never been more satisfying.
[*]Order Puzzles, in which you need to move coloured pillars onto switches or underneath obstacles in such a way that changing colour will either activate the correct switch or make it so that you can jump onto your impromptu platform respectively.[/list] 

Every so often, a new element—different shapes of block, spigots of paint that will change the colour of said blocks, lazers, etc—is added, which keeps gameplay fresh. I found myself smiling on more than one occasion when I figured out how several elements worked in conjunction with each other.

The mixture of puzzle solving with stretches of less taxing platforming during which your mother speaks to you while you press onward is effective in fully immersing you in the worlds of Hue. Your mother serves as the narrator, communicating with you via letters scattered throughout the world, and the tone and pace of narration is just lovely. 

In fact, the soundtrack as a whole is a wondrous, somber collection of melodies played on classical instruments that fits the game’s atmosphere to a T. It’s reminiscent of a more upbeat [i]Limbo[/i] where no horrors lurk in gloom and tasked with adding a splash of colour to the shades of gray. It also embraces [i]Limbo[/i]'s instant-death formula where taking damage ends Hue’s life.


.Pros.
[list] [*] The game is gorgeous. From the aesthetics to the soundtrack, it’s simply a treat to experience. 
[*] The story is wound throughout gameplay organically and aids in immersing you in the world.
[*] Collectables that reward your exploration. Picking up all 28 will require you to backtrack.
[*] Puzzles segments are satisfying to solve.
[*] New areas add new elements to puzzle solving, keeping things fresh. [/list]

.Cons.
[list] [*] The game is rather short for the asking price. Even though I struggled at the end, I clocked around 5 hours and I’m no puzzle expert. 
[*] The difficulty ramps up towards the end. This was very frustrating after having such a serene and atmospheric experience up until that point. This is a personal gripe.
[*] Checkpoints exist at the beginning of a stage. Insta-death means that messing up in the slightest (even if it’s at the very end of a puzzle) starts you over from the very beginning. 
[*] 
 [/list]

Here's some gameplay: https://youtu.be/mmJzegyqugA

.Bottom Line.
Hue is great—an indie gem that should be in your library. Period. There’s a lot to like here and, though the asking price is kind of steep considering the game’s length, the experience you’ll be embarking upon may be worth it. It’s up to you.

The gameplay is fluid and intuitive, the atmosphere is fantastic, and the story is the cutesy feel-good kind you’d expect from a Pixar flick.

If you’re still reading, buy this game.

29434958.review:
Hue is a beautiful, interesting puzzle platformer that I would definitely recommend to everyone. The game caught my attention right away, and I completed the entirety in one sitting.

The way Hue is played is different than most platformers in the manner used to solve the puzzles that you must get around. Your means to solving puzzles requires use of color, hence the title of the game. As you progress along, you will gain the power to morph the background colors of the world you are in. Doing so will cause any objects in the foreground to disappear if they share the same color as the background. You will unlock new colors as you play the game, and you can shift to any of them using a color wheel that pops up for your control.

That right there is pretty much the crux of gameplay for Hue. While it is also a platformer and requires some running and jumping, most of the puzzles do not force you to perform tight-knit platforming actions. They are usually more focused on the actual color puzzles themselves. A large amount of the game is easily doable, at least it was in my opinion, and not many of the puzzles will confuse you too much. But that did not make me feel bored, and the puzzles were not bad. In fact, I prefer when I can figure out most of the puzzles, instead of feeling like I would need to look up suggestions or answers.

The game does progress in difficulty as you go along, so everything is not the same. Each new area that you enter adds in a different level design, along with new obstacles in your way. For instance, later in the game will have some puzzles with colored gel spraying (like Portal 2), which can paint boxes into other colors, requiring you to figure out which colors need to be used to set boxes in correct places for holding switches or blocking lasers.

In terms of difficulty, however, the game does get a sudden spike in the final area. And the increase in difficulty here was not exactly positive for me, as it seemed like the puzzles suddenly degraded into being tedious and not as fun as the rest of the game. While I was a little sad with some of those puzzles, I still completed the game and overall enjoyed the experience greatly.

Important to the gameplay is the controls, and I will let you know that keyboard and mouse work completely fine. The game recommends controllers at startup, but I usually try games out with keyboard and mouse anyway. I had no problems whatsoever with the controls in the game. Everything worked perfectly and I could move around and react efficiently. In fact, the controls and motion of the game are extremely fluid - everything is smooth.

The art style helps show that too, with how your character moves, other objects bounce around and move in great motion. Graphics are amazing in Hue! You can see from the screenshots how the monochrome world can look, along with the changing colors. Other NPCs you meet, the puzzle objects, level layout with buildings and design - Hue is one of the prettiest games I have played in a long time. All of the colors fit together in such a beautiful way.

Music and sound are also quite amazing. I really love the background music as you play, with the soundtrack of the game having a decent amount of songs to cover your time. It really surprised me how comforting the noise is to the point that I want to listen to the soundtrack again right now. The only downside I had is that the game occasionally gave loud, bothersome audio fuzz or distortion noises, which doesn't occur with anything else I have played recently. It got better after I closed and restarted the executable, but it still didn't go away entirely. I really hope that gets fixed, because it damages the beauty of the game's audio.

Besides the music and sound, there is also some voiceover mainly related to narration of the story - and the story is something I have not gotten to yet. The reason for delaying my story commentary is that I was actually disappointed with it. While the narration you hear is pretty nice in voice quality, the story premise of Hue is nothing exactly new. Hue seems to act like it has a big philosophy... as if the story has large depth and great points about the world.

Some people seem to think that the story is amazing, but all it really does is try to argue about perspectives of the world. The main character's mother is researching this color technology, the ring itself that you control to shift the world's background as you play. She is challenged by a Dr. Grey at her university about the power of the colors, as if she is ruining something about the world by wanting to shift it from monochrome to colorful.

I honestly do not think the game actually gives you any new revelation or philosophy, though it seems like the developers think it will. And in fact, the game wastes a bit of your time because of their thoughts about the story. You "learn" about the story after every handful of puzzles in the game by finding letters that trigger narration sections. What the developers do here is have the narrator talk for a minute or two; and, in order to force you to hear it all without doing anything too confusing, they have you run through almost empty linear sections with no puzzles. The paths of these sections are intentionally boring and long enough for you to hear the entire narration without getting to the next puzzle. One of the sections is even a poorly-done maze.

Those narration sections intentionally waste your time, which is one of my big criticisms to the game. Similarly, the game has hidden collectibles called beakers, which also are meant to artificially bump up your gameplay time if you wish to find them. The collectibles do that because each area of the game requires a set of colors to get through the puzzles; but usually the areas will have one or two colors blocking certain pathways - colors which you have not yet received. What you will need to do is receive those colors from the NEXT area of the game, and you must return to the previous area, replaying the same exact puzzles until you find those previously-blocked doorways.

A shorter way to describe the above collectible complaint is this: Say there two areas of the game, A and B, with many puzzles that take a while. You must complete A entirely, complete B entirely, and then return to A, replaying almost all of its puzzles (with no difference from before), but use colors from B to find a couple of collectibles. It is a poor artificial way to extend the length of your gameplay.

Altogether, the game took 5 hours to complete, but that is with some idle time as well as those bad collectibles just mentioned. Further, certain puzzles in the game are rather lengthy for a single room, and if you die during them, you will typically repeat all of the easy portions over and over until you finally complete the more difficult part. I would say that the game is actually 4 hours or less, so it is not quite a long game for its price.

Despite the criticisms I have laid out for Hue, I would still recommend that you try the game out, as I greatly appreciated the experience.

29332344.review:
This game rules!

I've not gotten around to reviewing any of the games in my library yet, but I think it's fitting that I feel compelled to talk about this one first. I love platformer games, and this one's aesthetic similarity to Playdead's classic, LIMBO, caught my eye. Add to that a color-based main mechanic and a narrative-driven story, and you've got Hue. If you're into puzzle-platformers, this is a real winner. 

The color wheel mechanic (as seen in the trailers) drives the puzzles in the game: when you change the background color, any objects of that color disappear, allowing you to move past them. It seems like a one-trick-pony at first, early in the game, but Hue makes very good use of it and includes a great deal of variety, as well as some very challenging puzzles (the final level in particular is quite difficult). It also may seem like using the color wheel (which you control with the right thumbstick on a controller) would get in the way of the flow of a platforming game, bu it actually runs  very smoothly, slowing down your character as you use it so that you can change colors even in midair. Which you will have to do during the game.

The game's story mode took me about 4 hours, but a lot of it will depend on how quickly you can make it through the puzzles. There are also collectibles in the game, which will require you to return to previous areas after you've unlocked additional colors to access secrets, ala Metroidvania games.

The music in the game is beautiful. I've only ever bought the game soundtrack for one other game (that being Undertale), but I suspect this one may not be far behind.

There's even a colorblind setting. Kudos to the Hue developers for nipping that potential problem in the bud. So even if you have colorblindness, you can still play this game and enjoy it.

If I were to pick out one weakness in the game, it's the story. The narration is beautifully spoken and offers interesting commentary on the various colors, and there's always times to listen whenever you reach a room with narration. It's only that the actually conflict of the game ends up feeling a little weak at the end. Also, the game would occasionally minimize and go back to the desktop. Not closing down or losing progress, but forcing me to click back in (however, I have no idea if the game is at fault for this, or it's just my computer). But these are minor complaints. Overall, this game is worth the money, and deserves any bit of attention it can get. 

I really enjoy puzzle platformers, and the indie products I've played in this genre (LIMBO, INSIDE, Thomas Was Alone, and now Hue) keep me coming back for more.

29326259.review:
Hue is a game were you control a big-headed boy in a side-scroller, you must accomplish your objective by solving the puzzles in this dark and perilous world, thus, growing and losing your innocence, no, wait, that is Nihilumbra; no, wait, that is Braid, no, wait, that is Limbo, no, wait…
You get the idea, this is a completely overdone and unoriginal concept, the reason game designers keep making those it's because they almost always win awards. Loss of innocence is such a touching topic, but after playing dozens of games like these, I've grown to kind of despise them.
But this is not the main reason I disliked this game, I'll get into that a bit later.

In Hue, you live in a monochromatic world, but nevertheless normal. Now, your mother didn't invent colour, but she invented something to perceive it, and this research basically drove her mad and uncaring of her family, and the University she researched the useless idea of colour exiled her for trying to change the laws of reality, until the day something probably went wrong and she disappeared, well, she was warned, after this the University destroyed her possibly world-ending artifact and scattered the pieces. But your mother didn't disappear completely, she leaves letters that you can read, so she asks you, a little boy named after her research (Hue), to risk your life and commit the same mistakes she did so you can find her, so you venture out into this perilous and monochromatic world to save your degenerate mother.

But there is something worse that the unoriginal story, this game is nail-bitingly pretentious, my God, you get a new colour and your mother starts to be all philosophical, but she just spews things that the developers probably saw in the colours VSauce video, she also likes to describe trivia about impossible colours and visible wavelengths, things not usually known by the general public, but not impressive at all, her British accent also doesn't help, but maybe I'm just projecting. The thing I hate about this game is the same thing that makes me hate the Matrix series. Don't try to make your games, movies, or books sound smart and complex to impress people, when in reality it's actually something pretty simple and sometimes overdone.

The gameplay is clever, I give the developers that, so, you've got a ring of colours, and when you pick one, it changes the background to that colour, and everything on the foreground with the same colour, stops existing, and this game nails it on puzzle design, it's all really simple, and sometimes rather easy, except for the last few levels, where the levels start to get longer, and when you die you restart, if gets frustrating when you hit a spike by mistake and have to do the puzzle again. Also, the game's got some rather lackluster collectibles, you just get them for the sake of the achievement, that's about it. The games seems like a browser game at times, I've played really clever sidescrolling free puzzle games on my browser when I was younger. Yet this game will set you back 15$.

The graphics are also really good, all the characters are well drawn, and the scenery looks nice, the colours really pop out,, also the music is good at times, specially at the Electricity level. But it kind of feels that it works against the atmosphere the world is building, as in, your mom is missing and probably DEAD, but this lime colour is real cute though. Maybe the boy is happy by losing his workaholic mother, you never know.

Overall, the game is really unoriginal, almost like a Limbo clone, but still, it's got some really good puzzles and scenery, and you can always mute your mother's voice and turn off subtitles, that'd actually make it a good game. But the price tag of 15 dollars makes me unable to recommend it, but I also don't think it's a bad game, I'm neutral towards it in the end.

29270981.review:
Un jeu de réflexion/plateforme  qui rappelle certains mastodontes du genre en apportant tout de même du nouveau, mais qui ne leur arrive qu'à la cheville, faute de rythme. 

Braid, Limbo, Portal 2 sont les trois jeux auquels Hue m'a principalement fait pensé. Le design du perso et la structure des niveaux pour le premier, quelques éléments liés au Die&Retry et à la mort pour le second, et l'utilisation d'énigmes à base de couleurs pour le troisième. Que du positif à priori, sauf qu'il manque un aspect essentiel: une progression suffisemment captivante tout du long.
Les 3/4 du jeu sont relativement faciles, sorte de tutoriel étalé sur plusieurs heures instaurant aussi quelques passages narratifs  très "philosophie du dimanche", renforçant son aspect soporifique.
Ainsi seuls les derniers puzzles proposent un challenge intéressant, la courbe de difficulté passant du faux-plat à la pente raide très significativement, et bien qu'ils soient intéressants, ils ne sont pas assez nombreux pour inverser l'impression d'ennui ressentie durant la majeure partie.

En bref, un jeu sympatique à faire pourquoi pas en famille, mais mal rythmé et pas assez poussé pour être mémorable.

29117100.review:
색의 변화라는 컨셉을 활용한 퍼즐 플래포머 게임.

무지개색(+1)의 총 8가지 색을 활용해 게임을 진행해나간다. 특정 색깔의 사물은 배경색을 그 색깔로 바꿔버리면 사물이 존재하지 않는 것으로 되버린다. 이러한 특성을 활용해 물건을 옮기고 장치들을 작동시켜 출구에 무사히 도달해야 한다. 색을 사용한다는 컨셉 자체는 아주 새로운 건 아니긴 하다만, 그 컨셉을 게임 플레이에 아주 자연스럽고 용이한 방향으로 구현해냈다는 점을 높게 평가하고 싶다.

전체적인 그래픽 디자인이 실루엣 형태이기 때문에 림보를 떠올리는 사람이 있을 것이다. 하지만 림보와는 기본적인 컨셉부터 큰 차이를 보이는 게임이다. 또한 여덟가지 알록달록한 색을 활용하기 때문에 기본적으로 게임이 검은색을 띄는 건 어쩌면 불가피할 지도 모를 일이고 말이다.

색을 활용한다는 컨셉만큼이나 게임의 레벨 디자인도 매우 뛰어난 편이다. 색을 아주 절묘하게 잘 활용했을 뿐더러, 어느 정도 컨트롤을 요하는 파트도 배분이 잘 돼있다. 퍼즐 플래포머 게임으로써는 매우 뛰어난 수준. 난이도가 대체로 쉬운 수준이니 조금만 침착하게 고민하면 어렵지 않게 전부 풀릴 수준이다. 플레이타임이 4시간 정도로 짧게 느껴질 수 있겠지만, 더도 말고 덜도 말고 이 정도가 딱 적당하다는 느낌이다. 

다만 실험용 비커라는 수집 요소의 경우, 1회차 플레이에서 전부 모으는 것은 불가능하다. 최소한 모든 색깔을 전부 획득하고 다시 한 번 게임을 반복해서 돌아야 한다. 살짝 2회차 요소가 강요되는 감이 있지만, 각 챕터를 얼마든지 다시 돌 수 있고 한 번 먹은 비커는 그 상황에서 죽거나 게임을 그냥 꺼도 먹은 것으로 유지되기 때문에 모으기는 상대적으로 편하다.

살짝 조작이 미끄러지는 감이 있다. 이거 때문에 엉뚱하게 죽는 경우가 가끔 생긴다. 이게 개인적인 문제인건지 정확히 파악은 안 되는데, 만일 게임 자체의 문제라면 옥의 티라고 지목받을만한 부분이다. 이거 말고는 사실 딱히 흠결은 없는 게임이다.

숨어있는 여덟빛깔 보석과도 같은 광채를 띠는 게임. 이런 게임이 세상에 더 빛을 보지 못하는 게 아쉬울 따름이다.

29077632.review:
[u][b]Short Version[/b][/u]: 8/10

Not suprisingly, Hue is a beautifully developed puzzle platformer that takes color puzzles a step further than previously seen.  Hue will grab your attention right away, amuse you with it's novel puzzles and pull you along for the ride. Toward the end the game becomes a little tedious as the color puzzles go from novel to tiresome. Solid little puzzle platformer that can easily be completed in under 5 hours, and for that reason, the price is quite a bit high. On sale or rebundled, a solid 8 out of 10 in my eyes. 

[u][b]Story[/b][/u]: 10
The narrative draws you into the story of a mother and son, their relationship, and the omninous presence of Dr. Grey, the "enemy" of color. Restore the project your mother was researching in order to save her. In the process, discover a bit about how perspective colors your world and how a single piece of information can change your viewpoint. 

[u][b]Gameplay[/b][/u]: 7
Gameplay is extremely intuitive and well thought out. Nothing seems awkward, though timing may irritate the player from time to time. Toward the end the game starts to feel as if the designers were struggling to come up with new challenges that made the puzzles go from interesting to solve to hurdles to deal with. Somewhere along the way, the equation of fun got lost, though when a puzzle is solved there still is some sense of accomplishment. However, overall game play is very well done.

[u][b]Soundtrack[/b][/u]: 10
Extremely peaceful and lends itself to the game's environment and puzzling. The voice actors perform quite well and they blend seamlessly into the overall presentation. 

[u][b]Controls[/b][/u]: 9
This was one of my few gripes about the game. While a controller is recommended, and I played that way (Xbone), I would have preferred to remap movement to the d-pad and not use the left analog stick. This, however, was not possible on my controller. I tend to prefer the precision control that a digital off/on state allows on the d-pad and that one doesn't quite get with a stick. Sure, there is a point when the game recognizes that you've activated, but why would I want this on a platformer? It's like trying to use a Red Cherry MX switch and find the edge of the platform with less than ideal tactile feedback. I probably sound nitpicky, and eventually you do find that rhythm with your controller, but still, was tiresome.

[u][b]Achievements[/b][/u]: 6
Most of the achievements will be acquired through normal play, except the final one, which will require a bit of backtracking and puzzle solving duplication. They all work, so nothing to stress here. If you're looking for some fairly easy ones to pick up, this game will satisfy most of that desire.

28938558.review:
Hue is a puzzle platformer and here is my short review of it.

The basic gist of the puzzle mechanic is that you can turn the world into a set of colours and any object with that same colour would vanish. So basically suppose there is a pile of rocks or a wall with say orange colour and you turn the world orange that pile of rocks or the wall would disappear and you can pass through. You get the colours as you progress through the game. Once ou get a few colours the puzzles are basically hiding objects of various colours by changing the world to the appropriate colour. The puzzles involve switches over which coloured blocks can be placed, walls of different colours,lasers and so on. The puzzle design is good and there are a few interesting puzzles to solve but the game becomes quite repetitive till a new mechanic is introduced which are very few.

Also few of the puzzles make you believe that they need to be perfectly timed but that is not the case. Every puzzle has a way without involving any precise platforming which is not explained well until you figure out that this game is pure logical puzzles and does not involve any precise platforming. There are a few obvious places and the game has a mechanic where time slows down so that you can change to the appropriate colour. 

Pros
Excellent music which keeps you playing through the various levels
Good puzzle design
Heart warming story if you care about it
No precise platforming required it is purely logical puzzles and the time slowing mechanic is good and negates any precise 
platforming required

Cons
A bit repetitive
New mechanics are combined in a way where it is not explained in advance though the tutorials prior give you an idea

Recommended if you like puzzle platformers with good logical puzzles which are not too hard. The puzzles are fairly easy and do not require mind melting solutions. It is fairly casual game which is very easy to get into it. This is not a hardcore puzzle platformer like Braid or recursed which require out of the box solutions and involve game changing level design. buy iy for a stressfree puzzle platformer experience.

The player has the ability to switch between these “dimensions,” making objects of a particular color phase out of existence, while objects of other colors remain or are brought back. 28732600.review:
This is a great little puzzler! With an art style similar to Limbo and other silhouette games, atmospheric music, and a challenging but not evil difficulty with a great interface, puzzle-fans will enjoy this one! You play as Hue, a boy in a black-and-white world. Slowly, you acquire colors with the help of a mysterious figure, as you unravel the connecting story about an experiment with color gone wrong. You are able to switch between colors to reveal hidden platforms, doors, and other obstacles like lasers and paint to solve puzzles. The difficulty curve starts off easy to get you accustomed to switching between colors, and the switching mechanic is very fair, as it slows down time while you pick colors so you don't have to have split second timing (though at times you do need to think quickly). The difficulty increases steadily as more colors are added, and the last few puzzles are very thought-provoking but never impossibly hard. Save points are well-spaced and fair. There are several "run away and switch colors many times omg!!!" sections where you have to think on your feet but most you can take your time and plan. Music is great; very atmospheric. Honestly, my one complaint is that during the voice over story bits, instead of leaving you idle or doing them over actual puzzles, you traverse through a long maze of ladders, stairs, or jumps with no point except to keep you busy and to listen to the story. This means that you can be just holding arrow keys for a long time without any purpose except to get to the next area. Annoying, but not a deal-breaker.

10/10. Great puzzler.

28714273.review:
[h1]Hue[/h1]
Ist ein kleines Puzzle-, Abenteuer-Spiel. Ihr spielt den kleinen Jungen namens Hue und mit Hilfe seiner Fähigkeit, müsst ihr die Welt durchqueren, auf der Suche nach seiner Mutter. Im Laufe des Spiels erhaltet ihr Farben. Mit diesen könnt ihr die Hintergrundfarbe der Welt verändern. Damit verschwinden Objekte der gleichen Farbe um Hindernisse und Gefahren umgehen zu können. Im Spiel sind mehrere Briefe verteilt, welche die Geschichte Stück für Stück erzählen. Mit einer Spielzeit von ~4 Stunden ist man mit der Geschichte fertig. Die Musik ist sehr angenehm und bietet damit insgesamt ein schönes Spielerlebnis.

[h1]Für Erfolgesammler[/h1]
100% sind relativ leicht. Das ein oder andere Level ist etwas schwieriger und bedarf etwas mehr Geschicklichkeit als die Anderen. Ihr müsst dafür alle versteckten Becher im Spiel finden, welche zum Teil versteckt sind.
Was etwas nervig sein könnte: Um einige Becher holen zu können, benötigt man die Farben. Sprich man muss manche Level später ein 2. Mal spielen. Für die 100% spielt man ~5 Stunden.

Es gibt ein Guide mit Videos zu den Standorten der Becher:

http://steamcommunity.com/sharedfiles/filedetails/?id=768169562

28702510.review:
Awesome platform/puzzler! Played it in one sitting because it hit just the right niche between frustrating and "Just one more try!" Gameplay is around 5~10 hours, depending on skill.

Pros:
* Art Style
* Nice piano music
* Uplifting story
* Possible to get all achievements with normal skill
* Levels introduce new components at a nice rate. Game teaches you how to use them without needing a tutorial.

Cons:
* A little short (once you've finished, there's no replayability)
* Piano score in a few sections is a little jarring. Mostly the tense sections. (Fixed by muting those parts)
* If you miss a hidden section on your first go-through, it can cause a lot of backtracking.

Similar to "Thomas was Alone" and "Nihilumbra" -- if you've tried those and liked them, give Hue a shot! If you're a fan of the genre, it's a nice title that adds a splash of new while still keeping the tried-and-true platform puzzle style.
