Hue es una mezcla ejemplar de puzle y plataformas.
+ Los gráficos son simpáticos, inmersivos a su manera y funcionan muy bien; es muy agradable jugar y se entiende fácilmente. El uso de los colores tiene mucho peso (es una "oda" al color). Eso sí, habrá momentos en los que tendrás que fijarte bien.
+ La historia está integrada en el juego de forma natural. La trama es bastante filosófica y a veces roza la condición de [i]frase para Instagram[/i], pero en general es entretenida. Lo malo es que no te puedes librar de ella, y los monólogos son un poco largos.
+ Progresa con bastante ritmo y no aburre.
+ Aunque los puzles empiecen siendo fáciles, poco a poco se complican, y acaban apareciendo puzles muy enrevesados, originales e -insisto- difíciles. El diseño de niveles es casi excelente y merecedor de reconocimiento. 
- Digo casi excelente porque en unos pocos niveles la muerte hace que tengas que repetir el nivel entero, y puedes perder tiempo repitiendo el mismo proceso monótono para llegar a la parte difícil. Personalmente, no me ha importado mucho.
- Echo en falta un creador de niveles para la comunidad.
Me cuesta creer que Hue tenga tan poca popularidad. Es como Time Fcuk pero en muy bonito y un poco menos complicado.

28650062.review:
Never before has a game given me such visceral satisfaction just from looking at simple colours. Absolutely beautiful, and I suggest playing with the lights off so you can appreciate their vibrancy to the fullest. There's also an excellent, soothing soundtrack to keep you nice and calm while you're racking your brain trying to solve all the puzzles.

Speaking of puzzles, while the whole "change the background colour to make things visible/invisible" isn't a unique mechanic in games (I'm particularly reminded of Outland as a good example of this), Hue uses it creatively enough to always make things interesting and fun. 

Short and sweet, it's definitely worth a look if you're a fan of the genre.

Tout est parfait dans ce jeu : gamplay super intéressant, des puzzles bien pensés, mais pas trop difficiles, une direction artistique très réussie et cohérente, que ce soit dans les graphismes ou la musique. 
C'est frustrant d'arriver à la fin, car, j'aurais aimé continuer sur d'autre niveaux tellement ce jeu a de potentiel (peut-être peut-on espérer un 2 ?)  
La rejoueablilité est assez faible, la recherche des fioles peut donner envie de replonger dans le jeu, mais les puzzles sont connus. 
Bref, je le recommande à tout le monde.

The puzzles are fairly straightforward at the start but quickly become rather complicated, involving paint jets (that can change the color of objects), circuits, and more. I ended up feeling challenged but not frustrated. The story had a neat link to the gameplay, but there's not much there, though the voice acting is actually quite good. 28333443.review:
I first played Hue during Insomnia 58, it left an impression and when it was on sale the previous week, I had to get it. 

The art style is very stylistic. It won't take your breath away like a more realistic game like Steep but it has charm and a glorious use of colour that the whole game is based on. 

The gameplay itself, is rather intuitive and new mechanics are introduced throughout which helps to keep it fresh. Changing colours - the main gimmick of the game - is a simple and fluent process, the developers have incorporated it well into the gameplay. There is a little bit of momentum which can be annoying at times ("Goodness! Stay still box!"). The levels do get increasingly complex as the game progresses but except for one or two levels, they are intuitive and not frustrating. I really do wish it was longer though!

The music - very calming, very soothing (much wow), it really suits the game.

The plot is told via letters is thought-provoking, poignant and a touch philosophical. There isn't much substance behind it does raise a few interesting ideas.

And another completely relevant point - it's Hue, a game focused on colour. The pun deserves credit.

I really enjoyed playing Hue. It's a game that is very relaxing and although it does have a little short-term replayablity (you could probably play in a years time when you forget all the levels), it can leave a lasting impression. Would I recommend paying the full-price? Maybe. But if it's on sale and you want a short and well-made game? Get Hue!

Before I start, I'd like to say for those wondering, THERE IS A COLORBLIND MODE!!!! I don't know if anyone else mentioned it, so I am. I don't know about full colorblind, but you can play this if you're partially color-blinde! Go to options, under video, and check the box! The option comes with symbols that distinguish the colors. Also, because it took me like 10 minutes the very first time I opened the game, ALL your options are under ESC. Hit ESC to get the map, quit, video, audio etc. This is very important as game set-up is defaulted to WASD which is insane to get used to. You hit ESC and go into "Options" for the arrow keys instead. (it also lets you change controller keys).

10/10. BEAUTIFUL GAME. It took me days to finish. At first it's really easy, and then the levels get super hard with a few easy ones in between. Unless you're really good at puzzles-I had to play with my friend who kept solving it. Made my life easier. But it is no less fun. I'd say about 6 hours, and I'm not the only one. So, 6 hours of game play. 

The graphics are great. I love the colors, and they're easy enough to control to switch in between each other. The music is beautiful. The only annoying sound was the death sound because I hate crunching noises and I heard it frequently tbh. Especially 2 specific chapters near the end. The moms letters range from really good to kind of stupid and pointless, but mostly I loved her letter. Each color you find (one at a time) reveals a new segment of her letter. With on by the professor, second to last. I'm not really sure what the point of the game or the letter or the game is-I don't know why she didn't just come home by herself. I guess she was only able to come back with Hue? 

It was a fun game though, and hard enough (and fun enough) that once you finish the game, replaying it won't be that bad. The only achievement I haven't gotten was finding all the beakers. I'll have to continue playing the game now that I'm finished, for that. But ALL the other achievements can be (and are) won on the first run through, in other words: they're easy to get.

27710560.review:
优秀的理念，糟糕的体验。
3.5小时通关完成。完全没有全收集的欲望。
游戏本身理念非常独特新颖，而且出发点非常奇妙，画风又非常棒，甚至说是惹人喜爱。
音乐和颜色搭配出的氛围非常优秀，可以说是2D游戏界美的代表。
各个谜题难度不是很高，只要稍微的观察+动脑很容易就可以想出来。
但是必须说，如此优秀的点子却做出来如此糟糕体验的游戏，我也是醉了。

这个游戏真的很优秀，所以我就不一一列出来哪里好了，单说哪里不好。
1、重复性
很多谜题要花很多时间做一些重复的动作，费劲转一圈终于拿到钥匙之后，开门居然需要你把刚才的谜题反过来重新再推一遍！！简直没人性好吗！！！
我费劲来来回回爬上爬下做重复动作做了一整圈谜题解完了！你让我反着再重复一遍！
这种行为一次两次可以理解，满地都是完全就变成了拖延时间！
恶意浪费时间浪费感情！非常不能忍！我是来解谜的！不是来正着按一圈再反着滚一圈键盘的！
2、重复性！
讲剧情可以理解，讲剧情的时候疯狂拿冗长的地图脱时间，生怕你听不完剧情。
可以理解！没问题！但是你把以后拿到新颜色才能解的谜题放在之前的关卡里。
好啊，很多游戏都是拿到新能力再回以前的地图收集好东西嘛~可以理解。
再把冗长而毫无意义的图跑一遍才能过去！再把来来回回好几圈都是一个思路的谜题解一遍！
这种重复的意义是什么？拖时间！！完完全全的只是浪费时间！
你游戏细节再好场景再漂亮，你的关卡中终究没有值得细看留心可以观察到什么的地方。
把已经重复到让人厌烦的关卡再重复一遍？！你逗我？！
3、重复性！！
明知故犯！游戏中颜色的运用有时候真的让人发狂。
我举个很小的例子：游戏自己都解释：红色令人生气，让人烦心。
然后游戏中有好几个谜题，对手残很不友好！稍稍失误一下一切要重头再来。
但是！这几个谜题！偏偏在解难度较高的跳跃谜题时，背景是红色的！！！
一种令人心烦的感觉油然而生，然而你还强行不能急。当你无意中失误了！
抱歉！红着给我再来一遍！
当你重复了几遍以后，删游戏的心都有了。
而这类奇葩的颜色运用方式经常出现，有时在你着急赶路的时候还不忘用相近的颜色恶心你一口，真是够了……

吐槽了这么多我其实对这款游戏评价还不错，不过真的不适合操作一般般、不怎么擅长解谜、耐心不是【非常高】的人玩。
祝这个社的游戏越做越好……不要再让好点子烂在这种渣体验上。

（我说实话，同为做游戏的，我很多时候都在考虑：要不要让玩家来回折返两下，多制作（读作ctrlc+v）一些重复的任务和谜题。这样做起来既没有任何工程量，又可以有效增（tuo）加（yan）游戏时长。不过，随机+继承的多周目的游戏，其实还是很好的。）

再次感谢游戏制作人为我们带来如此优秀的创意和作品。谢谢。

25624517.review:
Hue est un jeu de plateforme-puzzle 2D développé par Fiddlesticks et publié par Curve Digital. Avant même d'être sorti, il avait déjà gagné 7 récompenses dans divers compétitions et festivals. Le principe est simple, on doit se servir des couleurs pour résoudre des énigmes et autres puzzles. Il est possible de changer de couleur (7 couleurs sont disponibles) et ainsi afficher ou cacher certains éléments du décor. En jouant avec les couleurs, il sera possible à notre brave hue (héros de notre aventure) de retrouver sa mère disparue il y a peu.

Hue est un jeu au gameplay simple mais ô combien efficace. On se déplace dans un monde limité en couleurs à la recherche de notre mère et on va devoir explorer différents niveaux pour y trouver des couleurs. Ces dites couleurs nous permettront de voir la vie... en couleurs! En effet, si l'on sélectionne la couleur bleu clair, on pourra voir tous les éléments du décor comme des plateformes ou des caisses des autres couleurs. Il faudra donc changer souvent de couleurs pour comprendre et analyser les salles contenant des puzzles afin de trouver une clé et d'ouvrir une porte se trouvant dans le dit niveau.

Une idée simple mais ca se complique très vite!

Hue commence donc tranquillement avec des salles simples qui nous permettent de nous acclimater avec le concept du jeu. On arrive également assez vite à certains endroits inaccessibles car utilisant une couleur que l'on a pas débloqué. Le jeu nous permettra donc une fois fini d'explorer à nouveau son monde afin de trouver des mystérieux gobelets secrets débloquant un achievement. La progression est logique même si on a le choix de l'endroit où l'on souhaite aller. Il n'arrive jamais que l'on soit perdu ou bloqué, on retrouve toujours son chemin et la voie du succès!

Hue ne se limite pas aux seuls puzzles logiques, il va également mettre à rude épreuve nos réflexes et notre sens du timing. En effet, certaines phases de plateforme viendront donner du piment au jeu et nous éviteront une certaine monochromie, heu non monotonie pardon! Ces phases sont assez simples et souvent drôles, il s'agit surtout de choisir la bonne couleur au bon moment et de changer rapidement après par une autre. Il faut savoir que le jeu est permissif et nous propose de geler un peu le temps lorsque l'on utilise la roue des couleurs grâce au stick droit de la manette.

Une belle histoire aussi mine de rien.

Au niveau de la réalisation, Hue est un jeu au design épuré et qui peut faire penser aux jeux Game and watch. Il tourne donc sur de très modestes configurations ce qui vous permettra d'y jouer même avec un grille pain carburant à une geforce anémique. La maniabilité est parfaite et si on rate son coup, c'est uniquement de notre faute. J'ai toutefois eu quelques soucis de choix de couleurs avec le stick droit mais c'est un phénomène plutôt rare.

Hue n'est pas qu'un simple concept amusant et prenant, c'est aussi tout un environnement narratif et une ambiance au top. Mention spéciale à la bande son que je trouve fabuleuse et qui se fond parfaitement dans l'esprit du jeu. Elle est certes calme et presque monotone mais elle apporte un réel plus au jeu dans sa dimension narrative. L'histoire est également excellente avec des lettres à trouver dans les niveaux et qui racontent ce qui est arrivé à notre mère. Tout est doublé magistralement par d'excellents comédiens, un pur régal!

Pétard mais je suis un génie!

Hue propose un challenge de qualité, ni trop simple ni trop abscon. On est souvent surpris par l'ingéniosité des puzzles et par ces doux moments on se surprend soi-même! La durée de vie est plutôt bonne pour un jeu de cette gamme de budget, il m'a fallu 7 heures pour tout finir et débloquer tous les achievements! Je ne suis resté bloqué que sur un seul puzzle avec des plateformes dotées de peinture mais après réflexion et l'aide de mon fils, j'ai trouvé la solution! Tout est logique et on se demande parfois pourquoi on s'est compliqué la vie sur certains puzzles.

Hue est une magnifique surprise pour moi, je n'ai découvert le jeu qu'après avoir acheté la bande son et je suis tombé sous le charme. Le jeu n'est ni trop dur ni trop facile. On s'étonne soi-même après avoir résolu des puzzles sans que le jeu devienne frustrant. Chaudement recommandé! 9/10

25420239.review:
This game is immensely enjoyable. Hue is a platformer puzzle game based around altering the world around you according to color. It has a very philosophical narrative to go along with it, along with beautiful music and smooth, fairly cute visuals. The animation actually somewhat reminds me of one of my favorite games, Super Paper Mario. I didn't fully understand every aspect of the story, but I was able to follow most of it and it was profoundly interesting.

Hue is extremely polished. I can think of one or two things that will likely be patched, but you might not even notice on your playthrough. For example, there's one puzzle (and I do mean one puzzle in the entire game) where you can trap yourself in an area with no way out except to restart the room from the pause screen. However, you can only really trap yourself if it's at the beginning of the puzzle, so you don't even have to reset very far.

Overall, Hue is a very enjoyable and unique experience, and I'm very glad I purchased it. I loved that when you reach the final puzzle there are multiple indications, such as the music changing, that let you know that you're on the final puzzle, and thus fill you with determination.

Hue is a fantastic play. Definitely recommended.

25382134.review:
[quote=Борис Акунин]Настоящую красоту невозможно запечатлеть при помощи фотографического объектива; она слишком жива и неправильна, слишком переменчива. А может быть, всё дело в том, что настоящую красоту воспринимаешь не глазами, а как-то иначе.[/quote]

Платформер-головоломка [b]Hue[/b], разработка которого, к слову, началась еще в 2014 году, предлагает нам оценить значение цвета в окружающем нас мире. 

По сюжету мы играем за паренька по имени [b]Hue[/b], проживающего в монохромном мире, который отправляется на поиски пропавшей матушки. Для того чтобы достигнуть своей цели герою предстоит отыскать цветные фрагменты, с помощью которых можно будет преодолеть множество преград, а также пересмотреть некоторые свои взгляды на жизнь и на восприятие мира.

Головоломки в игре поданы достаточно оригинально. Например, нам надо избежать столкновение с катящимся на нас красным камнем больших размеров. Для решения головоломки перекрашиваем фон в красный цвет, и тогда препятствие исчезает, и мы сможем пройти дальше. Но не думайте, что все так просто! Постепенно цветов в нашем арсенале будет становиться все больше, а пазлы станут все изощреннее, где-то у нас будет неограниченный запас времени на поиски решения, а иногда надо будет проявить чудеса реакции, отчаянно переключая цвета с одного на другой, иначе гибель персонажа обеспечена.

Хочется отметить важную опцию, предусмотренную разработчиками для людей, страдающих дальтонизмом, при активации которой цветные объекты будут помечены специальными символами.

Для любителей секретов тоже припасен сюрприз! На каждом из уровней разбросаны колбочки с жидкостью, спрятанные, между прочим, в труднодоступных местах. Если вам удастся собрать всю коллекцию пузырьков, то вы гарантированно получите ачивку и... моральное удовлетворение, а хотелось бы чего-то еще.

По мере прохождения мы будем узнавать новые подробности истории, о которых нам поведает приятный женский голос за кадром. Причем стоит отметить, что игра в аллегорической форме затрагивает социальные вопросы современного общества.

Про минусы сказать что-то сложно, так как игра отполирована до блеска, музыка и визуальный стиль отлично дополняют друг друга, создавая нужную атмосферу. Единственное на что можно пожаловаться, так это на малую продолжительность и легкость большей части головоломок, хотя обозначение сложности это скорее индивидуальная оценка.

[u]Плюсы:[/u]
☞ Запоминающийся мир и персонажи.
☞ Оригинальные головоломки.
☞ Трогательная история.
☞ Мультиязычность.

[u]Минусы:[/u]
☜ Малая продолжительность.
☜ Большая часть головоломок решаются в течение нескольких минут.

[u]Итог:[/u]
[i][b]Hue[/b] - великолепный пазл-платформер с ярким и красочным миром, наполненным интересными головоломками, запоминающимися персонажами и трогательной историей, которая в аллегорической форме затрагивает проблемы нашего с вами общества. Моя оценка 8,5 баллов из 10![/i]

25321012.review:
Hue is a colour-based puzzle-platformer. You are given a palette of colours and an array of obstacles, interactable objects and hazards in these colours. Each time you change to a colour, all of the objects of that colour disappear and you can move yourself and other objects through them. The core gameplay consists of switching through colours and manipulating objects, phasing some in and out of existence in order to make your way to the end of the level.

Unlike many puzzle games, however, these puzzles are always intuitive and never infuriating. You will usually know exactly what to do very quickly, and even if there is a little thinking outside the box involved, these levels are not particularly long or complex, so even later levels will not take more than ten to fifteen minutes in total to figure out, and can be completed in thirty seconds once you know what to do - though there are quite a few curveballs where you get close to the end and realise things aren't going to work the way you intended, so it's back to the drawing board! They are also well-designed; each level has a few hazards, but dying will never take you back more than a few moments. There are also very few situations where you will be stuck and need to reset the level. The end result is that you will never be too frustrated at a level. You will always know where you went wrong and what to do to proceed, and you will never feel that your deaths were unfair. Many times I entered a level, looked at it, and thought 'oh no, this is going to be a rigmarole' and was always proven wrong by how intuitive and simple it really was. The levels are always fun and interesting to play, throwing in new mechanics every few levels so you never get bored or complacent. There are also a few short pure platforming sections mixed in to shake things up a little and keep things varied.

As well as exemplary gameplay, Hue also exhibits a fantastic soundtrack and aesthetic. A simple, cartoony art style with snappy animation makes everything stand out, and really helps with making the levels intuitive. The soundtrack is an eclectic acoustic mix of mostly slow piano tracks, with the odd bouncy, fun song mixed in to keep the mood high. The sound design is also snappy, with everything having its own distinct, fun sound.

The one area where the game is not so great is the story. There are many sections where you are merely wandering down a corridor, listening to some narration. The story is a little interesting, but the writing is not fantastic, often very simple philosophical musings that don't really add anything to the game. The voice acting is great, but while these sections are short, they take a minute or so each, which is quite a lot in a game like this where levels are also short, and only serve to slow down the pacing.

Overall, Hue is one of the few puzzle games I have played in which I never got frustrated or felt the puzzles were unfair or padding (apart from the story sections). The levels being short really helps the gameplay, so that you are never stuck anywhere for too long. The level design is some of the best I have seen in a puzzle game; always intuitive and simple, but still making you think differently every time.

Highly recommended and one of the best puzzle games I have played.

25292980.review:
I've been looking forward to playing this game since I played a preview at the Norwich Gaming Festival and I have to say it doesn't disappoint.

Such a lovely game with a beautiful soundtrack, compelling story and well-polished but simple mechanics. 

The puzzles are complicated enough to get you thinking, but not so difficult that they become frustrating. As more colours are added, you have to think more carefully about what you will do next. EDIT: Until the lazers and goo are introduced, then things become a little more difficult.

Normally I dislike sections of game that require you to think quickly and press the right combos. Hue isn't like that, though. I feel I have enough time to make the correct decision and any mistakes I make are through to not thinking the puzzle through rather than not pressing a button at the exact millisecond it requires.

I think my only minor complaint is that it might be shorter than I would have liked, given how fast I'm picking up chievos. I think I'm roughly a third through the game (without going back and trying to get all the hidden items) after an hour of gameplay. EDIT: The game is much longer than the rate of achievement aquisition would have me believe.

Fiddlesticks Games have worked really hard on Hue and it shows. I would recommend it to anyone who likes puzzle games, or something quick and easy to play when they want to relax.

25258756.review:
I've only been into the indie games for few years now and I have to say Hue is easily one of my new favorite puzzle-platformers.

You play as Hue. As the story goes Hue's mother is a scientist who, with the help of another scientist named Dr. Grey create a ring called the Annular Spectrum. The ring is used to alter the perception of color. Unfortunately Dr. Grey gets paranoid of the rings power and Hue's mothers obsession with the project. Dr. Grey steals the ring and destroys it. This accidentally sending Hue's mother into a shade-like area making her invisible. This is where your story begins. You have to find all shards of the ring, put it back together and find your mother. Throughout your adventure you get to collect letters left behind by your mother. These letters explain what happened to her leading up to the accident.

The art style of the game is beautiful and full of color. The game might start out black and white but as you collect new colors, the game really begins to fill out and looks amazing. The level designs are right up there with the art style. They looked great and are very creative. Everything down to the way the levels look, to the way they were layed out, to the platforming and how the games unique color changing mechanic was incorporated into everything couldn't have been done better. 

The soundtrack to Hue was surprisingly large. The steam page says that there are 30 tracks in total. Most of the songs I remember hearing were very calm and soothing, which was very helpful for later on in the game when the puzzles start to get a little harder. Even in the beginning, the sound track to Hue made for a very casual feeling game. I personally didn't find Hue to be a casual game though. Maybe at the start yes but later on you are tested on your puzzle solving skills. The sound effects were very realistic. You get to hear a wide range of things from running waterfalls, to falling bolders, to flaring fires, to the creeking sounds of gates opening and even the simplistic sounds of moving a box. All of it sounded real.

The Good

- Controller compatable.
- No crashes or frame drops throughout the entire game.
- Awesome voice acting.
- Great story and build up with narroration from the mother. Could have been a very generic story if not for the extra explanation from the letters you collect.
- Narroration made me involved with the characters. Both Hue and his mother.
- Amazing controls. Responded very well. With one minor issue. (In "The Bad" Section)
- Very unique and fun puzzle solving mechanics.
- Difficulty progression is great. Later puzzles get more challenging and really test your problem solving.
- Fun and challenging platforming mixed in with their unique game mechanics.
- New ways to solve puzzles added throughout the game so the puzzles don't get repeatative.
- Collectable beakens for completionist that you can later go back and collect.
- 4 to 5 hours long.
- Great conclusion to the story.

The Bad

- No replay ability outside of achievements and collecting beacons.
- Colors didn't always register if I tried to change them quickly.
- Price 16.99, A little high for my liking. Personally more around the 10.99.

Final Thoughts

Considering I went into Hue expecting a copy and paste like a lot of other games in this genre, I was more then impressed. I completely recommend Hue. I would prefer a lower cost but to be honest the games story and overal gameplay experience would be worth the buy.

If you're interested - https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=qw9VH3h4ot8

25258617.review:
[h1]A Story Driven Puzzle Platformer[/h1]
https://youtu.be/-GNMww9esPo
+ The gameplay is fun and very unique. You have the power to change the color of the background. This will turn some things in the foreground invisable which will allow you to pass through them. You will have to change colors frequently to avoid obstacles while doing some light platforming to complete a series of puzzles.
+ Great narration by a girl who sets up the story of how she found a "impossible" color and is trapped in a unseen void and askes you to save her. She talks to you through various notes she has typed out and creates some very interesting theories whether or not we as people even see the same colors as others, and about colors not seen by the human eye.
+ Nice relaxing soundtrack 
+ A surprising amount of content
+ Great level pacing and variety that keeps the game feeling fresh the entire time.
+ I really enjoyed the minimalistic sort of black and white art style with little details that are appealing to see spread out through the background of levels.

25254635.review:
[b]My advice: GET THIS GAME![/b]

You might think “Why? It’s so expensive!” -- NO, SHH. LET ME TELL YOU WHY.

[i]I played this game for 3 hours straight in awe of the beauty and the story, the motivational words that it had for me and the deep expansive psychological intellectual content that it threw at me in tiny bits of little letters I could find.[/i] In the 3 hours that I played I thought I finally came to the ending of the game but it was only the beginning, I’m not even done yet, I was just given a different mission. But because I don’t know when this game ends, even for the time I’ve played, I would buy this game and I’d be happy.

About halfway through I became sad, knowing that this game might soon end and that Fiddlesticks Games may never revisit or make a sequel. In the time that I’ve been a gamer and a Youtuber I’ve kept a list of games that have a special place in my heart. Hue is in my top 5, along with Bioshock: Infinite and Life is Strange. It’s up there with big games from big companies, for good reason.

Since the beginning of this game I was reminded of the old timey cartoony style that this game kind of hints to, which is one of my soft spots. I [i]adore[/i] Steamboat Willie-type stuff and it directly ties into the historical aesthetic of Bioshock Inf, my top 1 game of all time. But enough about how beautiful this game is.

The gameplay is top-notch. There is a minimal tutorial that shows you everything you have to do to get levels done. There is a very gradual slope up of difficulty and there is the runs, THE RUNS THAT TERRIFIED ME but they were sequenced so well with the music and the story that I couldn’t help but wonder how these people didn’t make more groundbreaking games like this one. Once you play this game, you’ll know exactly what I’m talking about.

What I really think is interesting: even though the game only saves the level where you’ve started - making for some deaths halfway through a certain puzzle - I did not become [i]triggered[/i] or felt like this was in any way a rage game (although in one part there was a spiky roof that didn’t have to be there, see ep 3 of my YT playthrough, but it’s forgiven). It was challenging in the best way.

Extra notes: [b]If you love Bioshock Infinite[/b], buy this game. There is so much psychology and intellect being thrown at you in Hue.
[b]If you love Limbo, buy this game[/b]. It might remind you of it and it does a good job of being challenging.
[b]If you love collecting things, buy this game[/b]. There are chemistry that you can collect and a bunch of achievements.
[b]If you love casual, puzzles, good & smart story and a game that won’t piss you off[/b], buy this game. 

Pay for the things that are worth it in life, help out the devs their bills and maybe fund a sequel for this game. You might be missing out on a first hand experience of this game for a long time.

[strike]But for those of you who really want to regret not buying it, and because I love giving choices, here you go:[/strike] https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=ktV6w17sq2k

~

The idea of this game is refreshingly unique as you go through the magical world of hue, using colours to work your way through the different levels. However, the puzzles aren't necessarily easy either. Although some may find this monotonous, i found it as my personal reward for getting through a stage of puzzles, as i always wanted to know more. Also, colour facts!

Atlast, i have yet to finish the game so i cannot give a full verdict as for whether or not it's worth the price but if you enjoy a peaceful, tranquil puzzle game, that is aesthetically pleasing on the eyes than you WILL enjoy this game. 39466584.review:
Hue is a small puzzle platformer that wastes a good idea without developing or branching much of its potential.

In Hue, you change the background color with your right analog stick (or a popup wheel if you use the mouse), and foreground items of that color will blend and disappear only to reappear once you change again. This means you'll be able to do things like avoid lasers, going through blocks or swap the order of boxes if you blend them in the background.

This comes with a few decent puzzles among a majority of uninspiring one, mixed with some rooms that are more reflex tests than puzzles. You won't remember any of the rooms after a few hours of having finished the game, but you'll mostly enjoy them while solving them.

Unfortunately, while the background color as a game mechanic is a great idea, it doesn't do much with it from a visual design standpoint. No real visual surprises come up, no creative vistas with ever changing colors... It's mostly black contours/foreground and there really isn't much going on. The ideas presented in the forgettable story are interesting but recycled and not well explored.

A similar thing could be said of the puzzles. Many other puzzles have implemented fade-in/fade-out mechanics in the past; adding more colors doesn't necessarily mean you'll have a better or even particularly good game.
You get 8 colors by the end, but usually you'll use at most 4 in each puzzles, the others will be "the other colors" that simply don't matter. A vast majority of the puzzles would've worked with just 2 colors, and even then the mechanic isn't explored in depth.
To make things worse, two sets of colors are really hard to tell from each other: yellow+orange and fuchsia+purple will cause you more than one unwarranted death.


It's a decent puzzle platformer, but get it or play it only if you crave one right now.
It won't blow your mind.

39524791.review:
Hue est un jeu de plateforme en 2D qui, au départ, parait très banal et très simple. Pourtant cette façade est très vite brisée. Si la simplicité reste dans la conception du gameplay, elle évolue dans l’exécution et la réflexion nécessaires pour traverser les différents tableaux.  Et le gameplay en question est assez simple à expliquer : votre personnage peut changer la couleur de fond des tableaux, et ainsi, faire disparaître les objets de couleur similaire et/ou faire apparaître les autres.

Hue est vraiment agréable à l’œil. Tous les tableaux sont  hyper lisibles et ainsi on peut aisément comprendre le chemin à emprunter. Mais, il s’agit d’un jeu à puzzles et tous ne sont pas faciles à percer. Il faut des fois faire preuve d’un certain sens du rythme, parfois de pure observation ou encore d’une coordination importante entre les mouvements du personnage et les changements de couleurs.  

De plus Hue nous propose une aventure assez agréable à suivre avec une bande son très raccord avec l’action. Ainsi les phases les plus calmes du jeu sont accompagnées d’une musique douce et certains passages plus dangereux nous rappellent qu’il faut réfléchir, mais réfléchir vite. Un bon jeu de plateforme.
